For each model, we simulated 100,000 datasets with thresholds tuned to produce similar mean response times. The direct difference model had strong parameter recovery, with a mean correlation between true and predicted parameters of r = .96 for the training, validation, and test sets. Additionally, the direct difference model reproduced the empirical data approximately as well as the alternative-wise model, with posterior predictions correlating with true choice proportions at r = 94 averaged across conditions.

After validating the direct difference model's recovery, we next trained a network to classify the model used to simulate a data set. The trained network then yields the posterior probability that a dataset was generated from each model. This classifier network achieved nearly perfect performance when classifying the simulated data, with a validation accuracy of 99.91%. When classifying the empirical data, all but two of the 20 datasets from the first and second assessments of 10 participants had a posterior probability of > .999 in favor of the alternative-wise model. The second session of Participant 9 was assigned a .129 probability of arising from the direct difference model, still heavily favoring an alternativewise account. The only session where the direct difference model was assigned a higher probability was the second session of Participant 4, which had a .791 probability of arising from the direct difference model. Overall, we have strong evidence favoring an alternative-wise account of the present choice data. It may be that having participants complete a pricing task, where participants are required to compute the overall subjective value of a single alternative, promoted an alternative-wise strategy in the choice task.

div.head: Choice estimates
div.p: Having established the efficacy of the model, we can now take a look at its parameters as well as how they differ across conditions. Mean estimates across all participants for the fully-saturated model are shown in Table 3.

During the choice task, estimates of utility (α) were always less than 1, indicating typical decreasing or concave marginal utility. Estimates of log(k) also fall in the typical range; however during losses there was an estimate as high Table 3 Choice model parameter estimate descriptives as 0.87, indicating extremely steep delay discounting. Probability weighting (b) also tended to follow the commonly observed inverse-s shaped function given by b < 1. On the high end, estimates of b slightly exceeded 1, indicating an approximately linear relationship between subjective probability and true probability.

On average, we see little to no evidence favoring differences between gains and losses for the slope of the utility α function (BF 10 = 0.35) or delay discounting log(k) rate (BF 10 = 0.53). Despite this, probability weighting b was slightly stronger for losses than gains (BF 10 = 3.35). This indicates that rare outcomes appear more likely when outcomes are harmful -which can contribute to apparent loss aversion. Together, these indicate that dealing with losses does not inherently change the perception of value regarding amounts and delays; rather, keeping outcomes homogenous (only-gains or only-losses) allows participants to leverage the same subjective value computations to construct their responses with only changes to how probabilities are subjectively weighted to avoid large, risky losses.

In addition to the parameters that are specifically relevant to subjective value, we also have several important dynamic processes in the choice model. For these dynamic process parameters, the precision/speed manipulation produced higher estimates of thresholds (θ) in the precision condition (BF 10 > 1000), revealing a typical speed-accuracy trade-off. Non-decision time (τ) tended to be just over a second, with the fastest estimate being just over 550 milliseconds. Estimates also suggest a somewhat influential amount of between-trial variability (v d ), making choices on average move toward chance and accounting for slow choices that violate differences in subjective value. Given the relatively high thresholds we observe, estimates of within-trial noise (v s ) scaled to the diffusion rate of 0.03 rarely resulted in fast choices that violated the direction of the drift rate. Since v s had little impact on the choices that individuals made, we

div.head: Figure 8
div.p: Group-level posterior distributions for the utility, discounting rate, probability weighting, and price bias parameters. For the choice model (left), gains are in blue while losses are in red. For the price model (right), histograms correspond to buying conditions while lines depict a smoothed kernel density estimate of the corresponding posterior samples from the selling conditions.

might expect our estimates to be systematically too low, because the parameter was so difficult to recover that the network fell back on predicting values near the mean of the simulated data which was 0.4. However, posterior predictive checks where v s was manually increased shifted choices towards chance but did not improve the correlation between observed and predicted choices, indicating that higher estimates of v s alone would not dramatically improve model fit.

div.head: Figure 9
div.p: Results of the choice switchboard classification analysis for each participant (x). The height of each bar gives the sum of model probabilities in which each parameter varied between conditions averaged across T1 and T2 for each participant -indicating the likelihood that the corresponding parameter changed across experimental manipulations.

Switchboard analysis. Next, we evaluated whether the subjective value parameters (α, k, and b) changed across conditions using the switchboard analysis described above. To analyze the results of the switchboard classification analysis, we took the eight different models and divided them into models where the parameter stayed the same across conditions and those where the parameter varied across conditions, computing the sum of model probabilities for all models in Matching matrix from the switchboard analysis for the choice model. Each row shows the posterior probability for each model in the switchboard analysis for a participant.
which the parameter varied between conditions. This yields the posterior probability of a parameter varying due to experimental manipulations.

In line with our comparisons of estimates, averaged across all participants and both timepoints, we see inconclusive evidence for any parameter varying between gains and losses, with the mean probabilities of utility, delay discounting, and probability weighting varying between conditions being 0.46, 0.43, and 0.56, respectively. Looking at individual differences in Figures 9 and 10, we see a great deal of heterogeneity when it comes to conclusions about each par-ticipant's best-fitting model. An important note when comparing these two figures from the switchboard analysis is that the posterior probability of a parameter varying averaged across models (Figure 9) had much stronger recovery than each model individually, therefore we might see patterns in Figure 10 that reflect the best aggregate model without a clear winner in terms of individual models. Specifically, we find that 4 participants were best classified as showing differences in utility between gains and losses, though 2 were near chance. Likewise, 4 participants showed differences in delay discounting across conditions, and 7 showed differences in probability weighting across conditions, though most of these individuals were near chance. Table 4 Price model parameter estimate descriptives

div.head: Price estimates
div.p: The mean of the best-fit parameters for the pricing model are provided in Table 4. As in the choice task, utility (α) tended to be less than 1, however, we observe estimates as high as 1.89 in some conditions like selling losses. This is somewhat unexpected, as this indicates a strongly convex utility function, where the subjective marginal utility of an outcome is increasing. In terms of our pricing model, this means that in some conditions some participants were more precise when assigning prices to large payoffs than to low payoffs. This could reflect greater attention to high payoffs, corresponding to a stronger focus on the pricing task when the stakes were higher.

Estimates of delay discounting (log(k)) also fell into the typical range. Some participants appeared to have extremely high rates of delay discounting given by estimates of log(k) > 0. Most estimates of probability weighting (b) fell into the typical range below 1. However, in all pricing conditions, we observed at least some estimates greater than 1, suggesting that some participants display s-shaped probability weighting where low probabilities are underweighted and high probabilities are overweighted. This suggests that pricing may have an effect on probability weighting similar to that of decisions from experience (Hertwig et al., 2004;Hertwig & Erev, 2009;Wulff et al., 2018) -certainly this is worth exploring in future work.

For the dynamic process parameters of the pricing model, we observe moderate anchoring on the start point (ν). Across all pricing conditions, we see a large range for the strength of the anchor, with some participants only weakly anchoring on the payoff (ν < 0.2), and others strongly anchoring on the payoff (ν > 0.8). This bimodal group-level distribution is illustrated in the bottom right of Figure 8, where we observe a split between individuals' pricing strategies. This may suggest that group-level preference reversals are driven by a subset of the group that anchor strongly on the payoff, as opposed to a homogeneous effect that occurs for every participant.

The speed-accuracy manipulation had typical effects in pricing. Like in the choice task, the response deadline in the speed condition produced much lower thresholds θ than in the precision condition. Non-decision time τ was somewhat longer than in the choice task, averaging just over two seconds. Finally, the response time shaping parameter ω was on average just under 60, suggesting that participants performed accumulation simulation steps approximately 60 times slower than the scale of the price model where each step takes 30 milliseconds. This suggests that the mental simulation process driving accumulation in the price model may be as slow as .55 Hz.

For the buying task, the gain/loss manipulation usually had no influence on utility α (BF 10 = 0.13), delay discounting log(k) (BF 10 = 0.13), or probability weighting b (BF 10 = 0.13). Differences arose when comparing gains and losses in the selling task, however, where utility (BF 10 = 2.29) was higher for losses than gains. This resulted in more precise prices for large losses, which may indicate more careful decisions when taking on liability. Unlike utility, there was no evidence of start bias strength ν varying between pricing conditions (BF 10 < 0.14).

Averaged across all participants and both timepoints, we see evidence that the shape of the utility function (Mean = 0.71, Median = 0.82), probability weighting function (Mean = 0.56, Median = 0.54), and bias strength (Mean = 0.69, Median = 0.80) varied across buy/sell and gain/loss manipulations. However, it appears that on aver-

div.head: Figure 11
div.p: Results of the switchboard analysis for the pricing model. Price switchboard classification. Bars show the posterior probability that a parameter changed across buying-selling or gain-loss manipulations given the data.
age delay discounting was not influenced by these manipulations, remaining relatively stable across experimental conditions (Mean = 0.41, Median = 0.39).

Switchboard analysis. Averaged across all participants and both time points, we see some evidence of utility and bias strength varying across conditions in pricing, with the probability of varying across conditions being .71 for utility and .69 for start bias. However, like in the choice model, results are inconclusive regarding delay discounting and probability weighting, having probabilities of varying that were .41 and .56, respectively. Looking at individual differences in Figures 11 and 12, we again see many heterogeneous profiles. Averaged across time 1 and time 2, we see a very high probability that pricing manipulations influenced utility for 7 participants. Delay discounting appeared to vary across conditions for 3 participants. There is a moderate probability that probability weighting varied for 6 participants, inconclusive results for 2 participants, and a low probability of varying for 2 participants. Finally, bias strength appears to vary for 6 participants, is inconclusive for 2, and appears to be fixed for 2.

div.head: Choice-Price comparison
div.p: Comparisons of parameter estimates between choice and price suggest that differences in utility (α) and anchoring on the start point (ν) during pricing best account for choice-price reversals. Of the parameters directly involved in determining the subjective value of an outcome (α, log(k), b), only α varied on average between the choice and pricing tasks. For gains, utility was lower during the choice task compared to buying (BF 10 = 49.3) or selling (BF 10 = 142.8). This relationship is maintained for losses, with choice utility being lower than buying (BF 10 > 1000) or selling (BF 10 > 1000).

A more complete analysis of the relationships between choice and pricing is provided in the supplementary materials. In short, parameter estimates tended to be correlated between conditions within a response format (choices or prices), but choice and price estimates were not correlated. Two exceptions were that probability weighting b was not correlated between gains and losses in the choice task but was strongly correlated between all pricing conditions and utility estimates in the price task were only significantly correlated between buying and selling losses.

div.head: Individualized Choice-Price Joint Models
div.p: While the comparison of parameter estimates across choice and price models tests group-level differences in choice and pricing behavior, it fails to address how related choice and pricing behaviors are at the individual level. To compare the two response modalities for each participant, we leveraged the results of the switchboard analyses to develop individualized joint models of choice and pricing behavior. This analysis aimed to model each participant as a wholeincorporating those mechanisms that best explained their behavior on either task, and evaluating their covariances across conditions.

To accomplish this, we trained a neural network to jointly estimate the parameters of the choice and price models from each individual's data on choices, prices, and their associated response times across all sessions. If the switchboard analysis suggested that a parameter varied across conditions for a participant, that parameter was allowed to vary across conditions in their individualized joint model by being drawn independently. This resulted in a total of nine distinct individualized choice-price joint models -two participants actually shared a common pair of models across choice and pricing.

Next, a neural network was trained to estimate the parameters for each joint model. Rather than data from a single task, the input to this network was all the data from the individual, and the output of the network was a set of parameters that described their behavior in its entirety across all conditions. This is a novel approach to joint modeling, where two models of behavioral tasks are jointly estimated by one neural network.

Critically, dropout layers allowed us to draw samples from the posterior distribution for all parameters of the model at once (Gal & Ghahramani, 2016). The ability to sample from each parameter's posterior with hidden dropout layers enables us to calculate the covariance in parameters across tasks by plotting samples from individual pairs of parameters. As a result, we approximate the full posterior rather than simply the marginal error of each parameter (Sokratous et al., 2023). Matching matrix from the switchboard analysis for the pricing model. Each row shows the posterior probability for each model in the switchboard analysis for a participant.

To compare choice and pricing at an individual level, we calculate the correlation between 1,000 samples from each parameter's posterior. Key comparisons of interest are utility (α), probability weighting (b), and delay discounting (k) across choice and price tasks. For most participants, their joint models suggest little-to-no relationship across the choice and price tasks for any of the parameters involved in subjective value, as illustrated in Figure 13. However, participants 5, 6, and 10 all had substantial correlations between some parameters of interest.

Participant 5 had a correlation of r = .39 between the delay discounting parameter for gains in the choice task and for all conditions in the price task, but they had a correlation of only r = .15 for losses in the choice task compared to the price task. Participant 6 had moderate to strong correlations between choice and pricing for the delay discounting parameter. Specifically, delay discounting for the choice task correlated with delay discounting in all conditions of the price task (rs > .6). In addition, there was a small correlation between probability weighting in the choice task and the price task when selling losses (r = .3). However, these results should be taken with a grain of salt -because delay discounting was also strongly correlated with between-trial (v d ; r = .83) and within-trial variability (v s ; r = .79), which may indicate that delay discounting was difficult to estimate for this partici-pant's data. Participant 10 once again shows evidence of only delay discounting being related across tasks, with a moderate correlation of r = .5 between choice gains and all conditions in the price task and a weak correlation of r = .43 between choice losses and the price task. Though, we again observe stronger correlations with choice variability parameters (rs > .57).

The posterior distributions for the parameters allowed to vary in the switchboard analysis and posterior predictive checks from the joint models are provided on the Open Science Framework at osf.io/g2ua5. Overall, the individualized joint models support the conclusions drawn from group-level parameter comparisons at the individual level: there is little relationship between behavior in the choice and price tasks. The only parameter with some support for being related across tasks for three of the 10 participants was delay discounting. Even then, participants either had weak correlations between posterior samples or had numerous other strong correlations with theoretically unrelated parameters in the model, suggesting that the models might have struggled to accurately capture the influence of delay on subjective value for those participants.
Together, these results strengthen many of our previous inferences: 1) the gain/loss manipulation appeared to have little influence on average during the choice task, except for

It would not be appropriate to model all individuals as having the same values for α, log(k), and b. 2) During the pricing task, gain/loss/buy/sell manipulations most strongly influenced estimates of utility. In particular, the selling-loss condition yielded more linear utility. 3) On average, choiceprice reversals are driven by differences in utility and anchoring processes in pricing. However, this is not to say that choice and price elicitation procedures share a common value function. While choice and pricing elicitation procedures produced similar distributions of parameter estimates, an individual's latent representation of subjective value for an amount, delay, and probability in one elicitation procedure appeared to have little bearing on the subjective value that they assigned to the exact same amount, delay, and probability in another elicitation procedure. This holds true despite highly reliable behavior and parameter estimates within each elicitation procedure.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The objective of this study was to develop a unified modeling framework to investigate how subjective value is computed across manipulations of choice, types of pricing, gains, losses, and time pressure. The fit of these models to the data showed that this framework provides extremely good predictions of choices, price judgments, and the response times associated with each type of response. Despite the close fits to data, however, the conclusions about subjective value are more mixed. If there is anything to conclude here, it is that there are substantial individual differences in the computation of subjective value and how this computation varies across experimental manipulations.

Despite this, there are a few take-aways from the behavioral and model-based results. First, we found consistently that pricing tends to favor larger payoffs compared to choice. Furthermore, when grappling with the prospect of losing money, larger payoffs were weighted more heavily compared to options with a chance to gain money. This was reflected in the more linear utility functions in the pricing task -resulting in stronger responses to high-payoff (low-probability) prospects.

Choice-price preference reversals occur frequently under conditions of risk or delay (Lichtenstein & Slovic, 1971;Kvam et al., 2021;. These preference reversals are thought to be due to differences in attentional processes, where payoffs are given greater weight than either risk or delay during pricing compared to choice (Tversky et al., 1990;Alós-Ferrer & Ritschel, 2022). These dynamics are captured in the pricing model through modulating the bias strength parameter that determines the strength of initial anchoring on the payoff. In this study, preference reversals were less common, potentially due to dilution of attention (Kim et al., 2012) between all three properties of the prospect (amount, risk, and delay). This interpretation is supported by 3 out of 4 instances of preference reversals occurring when participants priced a larger, risky, later outcome as more valuable than a smaller, safe, sooner outcome, while choosing the opposite. In other words, preference reversals were frequent when the payoff was the only aspect favoring the larger outcome, suggesting that greater attention to the payoff in pricing drove preference reversals.

div.head: A singular subjective value?
div.p: If choice-price reversals can be attributed entirely to anchoring resulting from attention or attribute compatibility, we might expect nearly identical parameter estimates in pricing and choice tasks. Anchoring on the payoff may reflect a scale compatibility effect, where attributes that are represented by units that are compatible with the response are given greater attention (Tversky et al., 1990). The pricing model includes the start-point bias, which does not exist in the choice task, which would allow it to explain preference reversals arising from anchoring. We did observe substantial anchoring in the pricing task for many participants, indicating that this is certainly contributing to reversals if not explaining them entirely.

Conversely, if the choice-price reversals are strictly due to differences in subjective value, then we would expect systematic differences in the parameters related to subjective value. Specifically, we would expect the utility parameter to be higher (α; less strong decreasing marginal utility), the probability weighting parameter to be lower (b; stronger risk-seeking), and/or the delay discounting parameter to be lower in pricing (log(k); increased self-control) compared to choice. Of these, we only observed differences in the utility function (α), where pricing corresponded to more linear relationship between payoff and subjective value. This may in part reflect greater attention to the payoff during pricing, lending support to the attentional account of preference reversals (Kim et al., 2012). Moreover, model parameter estimates also suggest that participants strongly anchored on the payoff during the pricing task. Together, these results suggest that preference reversals, where pricing favors larger payoffs, do not arise purely from differences in subjective value, but are jointly determined by anchoring and more linear utilities in the pricing condition.

While the behavioral data indicated a slightly higher proportion of choices where the larger outcomes was judged as having greater value when the outcomes were losses compared to gains, we see little evidence of any differences in representations of subjective value on average except for slightly stronger probability weighting for losses, reflecting greater risk-aversion -a finding that runs contrary to expectations of greater risk-seeking for losses (Kahneman & Tversky, 1979). A lack of strong differences may simply reflect a lack of loss aversion for small payoffs (Zeif & Yechiam, 2022). However, individual differences reveal a great deal of heterogeneity in response to gain/loss manipulations. While in the aggregate gains and losses appear to be treated about the same in the choice task, switchboard analyses of individuals reveal that many participants are likely to show differences in utility and probability weighting functions, with occasional differences in delay discounting.

The pricing task paints a similar picture, where on average there was no evidence of differences in subjective value or anchoring processes between gains and losses in the buying task, however, selling losses revealed flatter, more linear utility and probability weighting functions. Some have suggested that the endowment effect from buy/sell manipulations reflects ownership rather than loss aversion, where the payoff that is owned is assigned higher prices than the payoff that is not owned (Morewedge et al., 2009;Yechiam, 2019). Selling losses is an interesting case because, from an ownership perspective, you are demanding payment to take on a loss you do not own. If ownership is the only explanation for the endowment effect, we would expect selling losses to mirror buying gains and selling gains to mirror buying losses. We do not observe this pattern, meaning that endowment is insufficient to explain the pattern of results present here.

A final key insight gained from the unified model framework in this paper is that, while choice and pricing tasks reveal similar degrees of decreasing marginal utility, delay discounting, and probability weighting on average, an individual's behavior in one task poorly predicts their behavior in another task. Utility did not correlate between the choice and pricing tasks, nor did delay discounting, nor probability weighting. While different elicitation procedures can be well-fit by the same descriptive models of subjective value, it appears that when we measure an individual's behavior in choice, we gain almost no information about their behavior in pricing. This challenges common notions of "impulsive" or "risk averse" individuals, where behavior in one procedure represents a general trait (Strickland & Johnson, 2021;Frey et al., 2017). Previous literature found strong correlations between two types of choice tasks (Wan et al., 2023), but our results suggest that an individual's impulsivity might be specific to a particular response process.

div.head: Limitations and future directions
div.p: A clear limitation of the present work is the small sample size. We chose to extensively test 10 participants across various conditions to allow us to develop and test highfidelity theories of the dynamic processes underlying preference (Smith & Little, 2018). All conditions were delivered twice with performance incentives to obtain a rich dataset for each participant. This allowed us to verify the test-retest reliability of our measures, models, and model-fitting methods. However, our small number of participants makes it difficult to connect model parameters between tasks or generalize specific insights into the mechanisms driving phenomena to a broader population. Such an endeavor would likely have to compromise on the number of trials and conditions to be tractable for a large number of participants.

Naturally, model misspecification is always a risk of making conclusions through the lens of a particular modeling approach. In "open-world" modeling, we cannot be sure that the true model is in the consideration set, meaning that even a switchboard analysis like the one we present here is unlikely to include the best model of behavior on the tasks. Idiosyncrasies in individual strategies, i.e. in the true model itself, undoubtedly affect the conclusions about which of our models fit best. However, by including more and more realistic cognitive mechanisms, we can start to divvy up systematic behavior and error into realistic explanations. And by drawing on both economic and cognitive modeling, we can at least discuss behavior on different tasks in terms of a language (risk-taking, delay discounting) that is common to both fields.

Future directions might also aim to test specific mechanisms rather than the broad set we entertain here, allowing for fewer conditions (or fewer trials) and a larger sample for each condition. Because of the individualized joint models, a larger number of participants makes the entire endeavor more complex, but it seems possible to automate certain parts of the switchboard analysis followed by a joint modeling procedure.

The addition of eye-tracking would additionally help incorporate a model of attention to test if anchoring is related to fixations on the payoff during pricing. Gaze could also be used to inform weighting coefficients for each component of Equation 4. Eye-tracking may also be an avenue to investigate the bimodal group-level distribution of anchoring strength (ν) in pricing. For instance, gaze may be different between individuals who anchor strongly on the payoff during pricing (initially fixate on the payoff) compared to those who anchor weakly (initially fixate on other attributes or a shorter initial fixation on the payoff). Likewise, joint modeling neural and behavioral measures might benefit from a parameter that influences the variance of response times, such as ω presented here, giving insight into the timescale of mental simulation in value-based decisions.

Another key direction to carry this work is to multioutcome and mixed gambles including both gains and losses in the same prospect. Although our tests of differences between gain and loss conditions here shed light onto what processes differ according to framing, a complete understanding of loss aversion requires presenting both losses and gains in the same choices or pricing judgments (Yechiam, 2019). Indeed, pricing might be a clear way to determine if someone is loss aversion: assuming equal-probability and equalmagnitude gains and losses (e.g., 50% chance of +$20 and 50% chance of -$20), being willing to pay to avoid versus pay to play might be highly diagnostic of attitudes toward losses and gains. Of course, fully accounting for these kinds of pricing decisions requires understanding other processes like anchoring and probability weight -requiring a model like the one we developed here.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This paper has developed a modeling framework that unites descriptive theory and dynamic cognitive models to characterize choice and prices under delay and risk. The goal of this undertaking was to identify if and how apparent subjective value changes as a function of the task and conditions a person completes. Our results support the idea that choiceprice preference reversals arise in part from greater attention to the payoff during pricing compared to choice, corresponding to an anchoring process that exists in pricing but not in choice. However, the shape of utility and probability weighting functions also appear to be affected by response type and condition manipulations, and individual-level parameters related to subjective value do not match across different tasks. We urge caution in comparing subjective value across different elicitation methods, and further work should evaluate the consistency of these valuation processes in methods like bidding, probability or delay equivalents, and various methods of eliciting indifference points. We hope that the models we developed here help understand how these many factors interact to produce the complex choice and pricing behavior people exhibit.
